The modern College of Architects Building may not be the most natural fit for this historic area, but the three-sided frieze by Picasso is a gem that adds to the ambiance of Plaça Nova. Picasso’s drawing represents Catalan traditions. It is simply, elegant and beautiful. Sits across from the Roman ruins and the Barca letters, near the cathedral, so it doesn’t require going far out of your way to enjoy it. Be sure to check out the frieze in one of the few places you are going to see a work of Picasso outside and for free!

While not a standalone destination, this wall adds to the historical richness of its location. Facing the Barcelona Cathedral, as well as the gateway of the Roman Fort structure, icons of major historical periods all come together. For this alone, I think a long pause here is well worth anyone’s time. The Picasso Wall is also a good spot to consider your next destination. Down one direction, past the wall, is Portal de l’Angel, a street full of modern shopping and good eating, that eventually ends at Plaza de Catalunya. Portal de l’Angel feels much more secure than Las Ramblas and offers more variety. If modern shopping is not your thing, turn your back on the Picasso Wall to walk in the opposite direction. You will be facing the remains of the ancient Roman Fort. Walk through the Roman gateway, and you are then in the heart of the Gothic Quarter with the Barcelona Cathedral to your left or, straight ahead, a main walkway (Carrer Bisbe) that accesses the winding maze of the medieval streets. If you’d prefer to see more Picasso, keep straight on Carrer Bisbe until it opens into a large square, the Plaza de Sant Jaume. Turn left onto Carrer Jaume which is soon called Carrer de la Princessa. This street will lead you to the Picasso museum!

We saw this while exploring the Barri Gotico. It's great public art, but by no means a destination stop. If you are in the area you'll probably come across it even if you don't intend to. If you're not, you can skip it.

This is a very nice (and free) opportunity to see a Picasso. The story behind this is also interesting, it was an statement against the dictatorship - and some say it was only put on the wall because Picasso was angry that Mirò made and exposition on this theme, and on his view he didn't deserve all that attention; so his artwork should be on an even greater and more public display.
Picasso provided the design for the side of the College of Architecture building.  It was an anti-Franco statement.  It is interesting to see.

Spend a few minutes reading the history to appreciate what you're seeing. Not many places can boast a large Picasso in a public space. Check out the gift shop as well, focusing on local architects and other design-oriented unique gifts.

However the best feature to the building is the public Picasso painted on the exterior celebrating Catalan culture including its on dance as well celebrate human pyramids. Wonderful to see when walking around the Cathedral.
